dt: {bc}to hit with a sharp slapping blow usually with an instrument (such as a bat or flyswatter)

dt.t: {it}swatted{/it} the ball for a home run

et: English dialect, to squat, alteration of English {it}squat{/it}
shortdef: to hit with a sharp slapping blow usually with an instrument (such as a bat or flyswatter)
a long hit in baseball; especially : home run

dt: {bc}to make a false report of an ongoing serious crime in order to elicit a response from law enforcement (such as the dispatch of a SWAT unit)

dt.t: Special FBI Agent John Bennett of San Francisco said in a statement to CBS, that those who {wi}swat{/wi} want to see "a tactical response" – specifically, they "want to see armed officers, they want to see a bomb, dogs, helicopters – that's all part of the fun."

The congresswoman had just been "{wi}swatted{/wi}," or subjected to a malicious act in which a person hides their identity, then calls the cops and reports a violent crime at the address of whomever they're targeting.

utxt.t: Prosecutors say that in addition to initiating the {wi}swatting{/wi} episode in Kansas … Mr. Barriss made dozens of other, similar calls to emergency and law enforcement agencies across the country during which he falsely reported bomb threats, active shootings and other criminal activity at high schools, shopping malls and even the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

aq.auth: Matt Stevens and Andrew R. Chow

shortdef: to make a false report of an ongoing serious crime in order to elicit a response from law enforcement (such as the dispatch of a SWAT unit)

dt: {bc}a police or military unit specially trained and equipped to handle unusually hazardous situations or missions

shortdef: a police or military unit specially trained and equipped to handle unusually hazardous situations or missions

dt: river 400 miles (644 kilometers) long in Pakistan flowing into the Kabul River

shortdef: river 400 miles (644 kilometers) long in Pakistan flowing into the Kabul River

et: English dialect, sweat, from Middle English {it}swot{/it}, from Old English {it}swāt{/it} {ma}{mat|sweat|}{/ma}
